title: Margie Cox
text:
Margaret Cox is an American singer. She is best known as the lead singer of the <a href="Minneapolis%20sound">Minneapolis sound</a> band <a href="Ta%20Mara%20and%20the%20Seen">Ta Mara and the Seen</a>, and for her work with <a href="Prince%20%28musician%29">Prince</a>.
Early life and career.
Cox was born in <a href="Kenitra">Kenitra</a>, <a href="Morocco">Morocco</a> and moved to <a href="Minneapolis">Minneapolis</a> with her family when she was seven years old. She learned to play several instruments, including piano, guitar, and drums.
Cox attended Southeast Alternatives Free School, graduating from Marshall-University High School and sang in the nightclub Bootlegger Sam's in Dinkytown when she was in ninth grade. Influenced early on by R&B and rock icons of the era like <a href="Stevie%20Wonder">Stevie Wonder</a>, <a href="Chaka%20Khan">Chaka Khan</a>, <a href="Aretha%20Franklin">Aretha Franklin</a>, and <a href="Led%20Zeppelin">Led Zeppelin</a>, she became known for her soulful, powerful vocals, and soon graduated to other bands, including Raggs in 1980, the Doug Maynard Band, the T.C. Jammers, the Peterson-Cox Band (with Patty Peterson), Rupert's Orchestra and, in 1987, <a href="Dr.%20Mambo%27s%20Combo">Dr. Mambo's Combo</a> (often referred to simply as "the Combo"). She has won numerous Minnesota Music Awards for her contributions to the Twin Cities music scene.
She also sang on a local "Bar Wars" compilation LP and on the final <a href="Lipps%2C%20Inc">Lipps, Inc</a> album, 1983's "4".
Ta Mara and The Seen.
In 1985 Cox formed a band called The Seen and was noticed by <a href="Jesse%20Johnson%20%28musician%29">Jesse Johnson</a>, guitarist with Minneapolis band <a href="The%20Time%20%28band%29">The Time</a>. Johnson renamed Cox "Ta Mara" and helped the band sign a deal with A&M. He also produced their first album, "<a href="Ta%20Mara%20%26amp%3B%20the%20Seen%20%28album%29">Ta Mara and the Seen</a>", and co-wrote all of the songs. The band had one major hit with "<a href="Everybody%20Dance%20%28song%2C%201985%29">Everybody Dance</a>" but in 1989 they broke up after releasing their next album, "<a href="Blueberry%20Gossip">Blueberry Gossip</a>".
Work with Prince.
Cox was a long-time associate of the singer Prince and his band <a href="The%20New%20Power%20Generation">The New Power Generation</a>. In the early 1990s, she recorded more than 25 songs with Prince for a band to be called <a href="Unreleased%20Prince%20projects%23M.C.%20Flash">M.C. Flash</a>, although the album was never released. She also covered Prince's "Standing at the Altar" for his 1994 compilation album "<a href="1-800-NEW-FUNK">1-800-NEW-FUNK</a>", and the song was released as a single.
Later work.
Cox co-wrote "I Need You" with Johnson, which appeared on <a href="Paula%20Abdul">Paula Abdul</a>'s 1988 album "<a href="Forever%20Your%20Girl">Forever Your Girl</a>".
In 2003 she released her first solo album "Margie's Little Demo".
She currently still sings with <a href="Dr.%20Mambo%27s%20Combo">Dr. Mambo's Combo</a> every Sunday and Monday night at Bunker's in downtown Minneapolis.
